newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Fine China makes its mark.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Fine China makes its mark.

text.p: China sparked up a market awash with sovereign issues on Thursday with its 500 million mark issue despite planned deals by Russia, Mexico and Cyprus.
The issue is at a spread of 55 basis points over bunds, and was lead managed by Credit Suisse First Boston and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
Traders predicted it would go well for a number of reasons.
"Partly, it's the mark factor. Investors really like sovereign paper in mark. Hong Kong and China are very much in with international investors in general," an analyst here said.
"If you want to diversify... into Asia, you're not going to buy Thailand. You're not going to buy Korea."
China, which had not done a mark deal in 10 years, was also expected to benefit from an upgrade by Standard& Poor's in May.
"We are in the issue," said a Hong Kong-based banker with a European bank, which joined at co-manager level. "It's very well received. It's a fair price."
Another trader with another German bank said Asians were interested in more European currencies, citing recent peseta issues from the region.
He said his bank was regularly running roadshows on European currency to Asian clients interested in diversifying their funding base and building relationships in Europe.
China was not expected to swap the proceeds of the mark issue, having a requirement to maintain a certain portion of its foreign exchange reserves in marks, bankers said.
China's issue coincided with planned issues by Russia, Mexico and Cyprus in Europe.
The expected US$300 million cross-border securitisation from Dah Sing Bank, a unit of Dah Sing Financial Holdings Ltd, did not emerge on Wednesday, when it was expected.
Gary Wang, general manager and financial controller for Dah Sing Bank and its parent, said the briefing earlier in the month had been to meet Stock Exchange requirements.
The deal involved disposal of assets within a listed group, and was also a substantial transaction, so an announcement was needed for the publicly listed holding company, he said
He said the issue should go ahead within a couple of days.
The Hong Kong dollar debt market remained unusually quiet, with no one attempting last-minute issues before the market shuts down for the first three working days of the handover to China week.
Including the weekend, this means a five-day break.
"There's nothing to report," said one banker active in the Hong Kong dollar fixed-rate market.
PT Dharmala Intiland and a special-purpose company Netherlands-incorporated company launched a US$45 million transferable loan certificates facility.
The five-year loan, is guaranteed by PT Dharmala Intiland, and has a put option at the end of year fours. Its margin is 300 basis points over Singapore Interbank Offered Rate.
With fees, the all-in returns for top-tier managers is 328 basis points.
Leefung-Asco Printers Ltd, a unit of Leefung-Asco Printers Holdings Ltd (LAPH), launched a HK$160 million term loan/revolving credit facility.
